comments.commentBody:
She is a lady. You will find an interview and photo at: http://chinadigitaltimes.net/2014/02/interview-human-rights-lawyer-xiao-...

May she and her kind endure in the China of today.
Having been career military, I'm used to everyone of the same responsibility level getting paid the same. On of the most disconcerting things about civilian work is the secrecy regarding pay.

If that were true...take Carla Fiorena, she managed to completely mess up HP, was fired and still got $42MM in retirement pay. Steve Balmer is another one, completely useless, and was still paid with no regard for the bottom line. People in leadership in the US are vastly overpaid by friends on the Boards and compensation committees, and the favor is returned wherever possible. Contribution and pay are rarely in line with reality..

The main achievement of China PRC has been to plot a steady course of sustained economic development that transcends politics as far as possible. There is only one special interest group in China: Chinese Communist Party.

Political dissidents in the West do not get many breaks either; judging by the response to Edward Snowden and his rejection of mass uncontrolled surveillance by the state. However America has a strong constitution written to avoid the abuse of power by an over-zealous government wishing to keep their mistakes a secret; out of convenience.

China never professed to follow the standards of the West; as if we are entitled to lecture them sanctimoniously? A country with 1,2 billion people finds it difficult to allow dissatisfied groups like the "occupy movement" a free licence. Lets face it even in Europe the state authorities now pressing for more intrusions into the area of personal freedom; without any public debate. Like every website visit monitored by every citizen...in China USA and Europe is now a reality. The impression is that foreigners are extremely patronizing when judging China PRC....the open-door policy never included the windows or the shutters?

Wise words. Some things in China are moving in the backward direction right now, which is worrying.
As a foreigner who lives in Beijing (though admittedly working in an area with minimal government interference) I personal feel no change in the last two years, except less corruption and an attempt by the government to start to enforce rules and laws more aggressively, but the stories I hear from people who do work with the government are not encouraging.

The Communist Party would most likely still be elected if there was a free election, but with the economy doing less well that becomes less certain.

Really? Because the main concern of readers (and commenters) in this paper seemed to be mainly worried about China eventually becoming a developed country.
Good to hear that someone worries about the well being of the Chinese people too - I assume you support the Chinese people as much when it is about trying to secure oil for their economic advancement, moving manufacturing capabilities from the developed world to China to eradicate poverty in China and the desire by the majority of the population of having a stable government.

Is it more important for you to make $100,000/yr or for you to make twice as much money as the secretary? I know that over the long term, my skills will pay off, even if they "floor" for some people less qualified than I am is relatively high.

I don't begrudge others their salaries. Heck, some flight attendants who joined Southwest in the early days became millionaires from the stock options. Does that mean I have wasted my life?

I lived in Idaho for 6.5 years.  Homeschooling is big there, and not only for religious reasons. The culture of Idaho is to hate having anyone tell you what to do, and that includes the government at any level, particularly federal.  It's a highly individualistic place up by-the-bootstraps, tends to be conservative, and likes to be left alone.  I'm liberal and could be driven somewhat crazy in Idaho during my time there, but I grew to respect the people.  Dan Price represents the best of the culture of Idaho.  In the end I'm certain, he will be fine, and so will his company.

"What others earn is none of their business "

That's simplistic. Everyone judges the pay they receive based on what they are peripherally aware, al least, of what they know others make. If you're offered $12/hr to perform a difficult task for long hours, you may think it too little, knowing that others doing the same thing make more. But if you're offered the same $12/hr knowing that others doing far less, with more time off, are making the same money, you might decline the offer and opt for the easier job that allows more free time. Comparing ourselves w others, pop therapy not withstanding, is part of making rational choices.

You might wish to study the history of communist nations such as China (and it's "cultural revolution" under Mao) as well as the former Soviet Union.

They implemented this, and on a large scale -- with the result being total failure, totalitarianism and massive starvation (when farms failed, because they were made into collectives, where everyone was "paid the same").

"Those who do not learn from history are doomed to repeat it."

Ally, exactly why this guy should've quietly given the lower paid employees the pay bump and not made a big splash out of it or let the press in on it. He might be doing what he feels is right,but by allowing this to go public he was looking for and got more publicity along with the unexpected flak. Publicity helps his company and he gets a bunch of " atta boys", but now he's paying for that free company publicity.

Based on this article, none of the employees who quit or are disgruntled had lost any part of their own salaries. It would seem they were happy with what they were being paid before others got raises. This means that they were not unhappy with their own pay, but with the pay of others. What other people are paid is none of their business and they should learn not to judge themselves based on others. Most of the criticism seems more like sour grapes.

Dan's critics are those folks who know the price of everything but the value of nothing.

I've always had a strong work ethic. If I had an employer do what Dan did it would inspire even more loyalty.

For the life of me I can not think what is wrong with being egalitarian?
What is wrong with instituting a wage system that allocates a flatter curve than corporations normally adhere to?
I wish I had a business so I could give it to Gravity

Boo hoo to those like Maisey McMaster, who were so upset that others were suddenly making more money even though your salaries didn't drop one bit. How sad that you were making a fabulous income and would continue to make a fabulous income while others suddenly didn't have to worry so much about making ends meet. Horrible horrible horrible. I am sure knowing that others wouldn't have to worry as much was such a damper on your existence. I am so glad you were bold enough to take a stand and quit.

Charging to do research is too vulnerable to corruption. A better system is to have research banks (which do exist) that are available to all oncologists perhaps paid for by their hospitals, cancer centers, or the government.
As a single subscriber to health insurance (which is astronomical), I don't want to potentially pay for any more corruption of funds than I am now. Who would conduct the oversight?
We already do. It is called taxes.

"Should we charge patients for medical research?"

That sounds dumb. We already pay for medical research when we pay taxes that fund research - even to the benefit of for-profit corporations.

He's right. The proposal is not as outlandish as it sounds. It's even more outlandish. Patients already are lab rats for researchers. The price of being a lab rat is risk. It should not also be money. Charging patients for research is a shakedown.

The idea that a member of a profession that lives by the Hippocratic oath would suggest charging research subjects to participate is a repulsive thought. Despite this fact, the idea that this approach is being raised is a statement of how skewed our society has become by capitalism. What we have is a doctor attempting to monetize his research subjects. Not only monetize them, but not even offering them a piece of the action should the research pay off!

If patients had to pay for participating in medical research, wouldn't they be likely to have advantages over those who could not afford the cost?  Better living conditions, better diet, more care in many ways that might possibly affect the outcome?  I imagine that all these considerations might affect patients who participated in free clinical trials, but possibly less so?
That is how it would work in "Brazil" or "The Hunger Games" or "A Modest Proposal",  complete with unimpeachable but (in fiction) ironic logic,
Have you checked the share prices of big pharma? Have you noticed their profit margins? We DO PAY FOR RESEARCH, and multiple houses, golden parachutes, 4th wives, etc.
No amount of profit is too much for these guys.

I was sputteringly outraged at the premise of the article until I came to the end and saw the authors' conclusion, that it's not a good idea, for several reasons, to ask research subjects to pay to participate in experiments. How refreshingly sensible.

I'd like to point out that we, the American public, are already paying dearly to participate in research in the form of co-pays and sometimes full-ticket prices for drugs that have been inadequately vetted by the FDA. Eventually, with enough AE reports--at best a tip-of-the-iceberg picture of actual patient experiences--drugs on the market can be pulled, retested, or their labels changed when sufficient data piles up to show they're causing problems or lack efficacy. Before that point is reached, American consumers and taxpayers may have ponied up millions if not billions of dollars for the privilege of extending pharma's testing window.
Stupid people who seek power to conceal how stupid they are will kill the planet.
I like Bernie, but he is a gadfly.

Unfortunately, they are very smart.

Since St. Ronnie, they have been robbing the country blind. Their current actions are meant to destroy anything that works for the majority of Americans.

The Republican Party is a business. They have no interest in anything but more money for themselves.
The Republican party is proving that it is just plain stupid.  Stupid is as stupid does, as Forrest Gump would say.

When I think about how much of my tax money goes to the war machine and corporate welfare, I figure that I would be better off just giving a portion of my income to those I know who actually need the money. We have allowed an economic system that supports the super-rich to flourish at our expense.

Changing that system will be painful.

I think you might be surprised at the priorities of older people, were they to be given choices between the things you have mentioned. Breast reconstruction surgery is funded in part because too many women were abandoned by their husbands or partners after the disfiguring removal of their breasts. How do you think that the partners of the sexually dysfunctional feel about the loss of a normal sex life? This is about maintaining normalcy in relationships, not about some alternative lifestyle.
How many boiler room operators and mafia accountants will be able to say 'I got my start with a taxpayer-funded college education, and I never went back to prison!'?

Sorry, Ms. Moses, I have never had a hospital discharge instruction that told me anything I didn't already know, and I have had several REALLY MAJOR operations.

The issue is really whether or not the President of the United States has line-item veto of specific elements of legislation passed by previous Congresses and signed into law by previous presidents.

Stop throwing up the emotional-blackmail straw men to cover your support of authoritarian government as opposed to the rule of law.

Just as hospital patients need decent discharge instructions and some follow-up care if they are not to wind up re-admitted to inpatient care, so too do former inmates need a plan and some follow-up services if they are not to wind up re-admitted to incarceration.   Trying to prevent access to higher education to inmates seems to me petty and vengeful, whereas providing access to college education seems to me pragmatic and constructive.  The numbers listed here about relative recidivism rates seem to indicate that college makes a practical positive difference.  Unless lawmakers want to confess that they really actually want to see former inmates land back in jail, it seems to me they need to make possible a path to a sustainable life that can actually be followed by released inmates.

The simile between Samuel DuBois and Cecil the lion reminds me more of Prometheus Bound than Adventism.  Minor theologians acknowledge the prescience of primal memory and its predatory nature.  Charles Darwin wrote, "On the Origin of Species by Means of Natural Selection" that as all the living forms of life are the lineal descendants of generations that have never been broken, the threat of extinction of major wildlife species is an existential threat to the human species as a collective as well.  Remember that in Aeschylus' "Prometheus Bound", Zeus & Prometheus squared off as they represented the forces of intelligence and the invisible symbol of force respectively.  Prometheus after all was the first great rebel of Western civilization as he represented the power of human determination against the concept of fate & concealed forces beyond man's control.  What is it that upset people about the death of Cecil the famous lion who was monitored hour by hour by the prestigious Oxford University?  Was it the repulsion of the hunter's all too human need to dominate & subject the powerful beast much like Prometheus' power to steal the secret power of fire?  Why does the collective human population mourn for the loss of a rare mammal whose power mankind has yoked & harnessed into near extinction for centuries? Could it be similar to the desire for man to remain autonomous from the 4 legged creatures as much as from the power & time honored Zeus himself?
